Controlling hydrocarbon oligomerization in phosphorus-modified CHA zeolite for a long-lived methanol-to-olefin catalyst Nao Tsunoji a * Ryota Osuga b Masumi Yasumoto a Toshiyuki Yokoi b * a Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Kagamiyama 1-4-1, Higashi, Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering Hiroshima University Kagamiyama 1-4-1 Higashi Hiroshima 739-8527 Japan Graduate School of Advanced Science and Engineering, Hiroshima University, Kagamiyama 1-4-1, Higashi-Hiroshima 739-8527, Japan b Institute for Innovative Research, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama, 226-8503, Japan Institute for Innovative Research Tokyo Institute of Technology 4259 Nagatsuta Midori-ku Yokohama 226-8503 Japan Institute for Innovative Research, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 4259 Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8503, Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The catalytic performance of phosphorus-modified CHA zeolites, synthesized by direct phosphorus modification using tetraethylphosphonium as a phosphorus-modifying agent (P-MA), was investigated for the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction. Comparative catalytic testing in the MTO reaction revealed that the phosphorus modification effectively prolonged the catalyst lifetime while hardly affecting the ethene and propene selectivities. The initial ethene and propene selectivities over CHA zeolite with P/Al ratio of 0.44 were 28.7 and 37.5 C %, respectively, and the catalytic life time improved from 4 to 7 h compared with the catalyst without phosphorus modification. The relative amount of non-aromatic hydrocarbons retained in the zeolite catalysts with respect to those of the aromatic ones increased with increasing degree of phosphorus modification. This demonstrates that the suppression of excess oligomerization of the hydrocarbon species results in a prolonged lifetime in the phosphorus-modified catalyst. Keywords CHA zeolite Hydrothermal conversion of zeolite Phosphorus modification Phosphorus modifying agent Interzeolite conversion Methanol to olefin reaction 1 Introduction Solid acid catalysts exhibiting molecular sieving abilities, such as porous aluminosilicate zeolite and silicoaluminophosphate (SAPO) materials, are important industrial materials that selectively produce desired products owing to the intrinsic acidity of the crystalline porous framework. The use of molecular sieve catalysts in the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction is the most successful process for the production of olefins from non-petroleum-derived carbon sources, such as coal and natural gas [1–6]. Recently, the rapidly increasing demand for light olefins (such as ethene and propene) and the diminishing crude oil reserves have triggered increased academic and industrial attention towards the MTO reaction [7–17]. Among the various structural categories, small-pore zeolites and related zeotypes with eight-member ring pores (8MR) and large cavities, such as CHA, AEI, and LEV (the three characters refer to the framework type code) [18], are known to be highly selective catalysts for the production of ethene and propene through the MTO reaction [1,13,19–27]. SAPO-34, a silicoaluminophosphate counterpart of CHA zeolite, has been commercially used in a MTO plant since 2010 [3]. However, because of the rapid deactivation of these materials through coke deposition, a fluidized bed reactor with a reaction-regeneration cycle is applied in the industrial MTO process [3]. Thus, the catalyst lifetime has to be extended as this will improve the process profitability. Based on this, strategies to make the long-lived small-pore MTO catalysts (such as controlling the pore structure, composition, crystal morphology, and acid properties) have attracted significant research attention [1,5–7,12,22,26,28–32]. In this study, we attempt to prolong the catalyst lifetime for the MTO reaction by modifying the aluminosilicate CHA zeolite with phosphorus. The modification of zeolites by phosphoric acid is a promising way to enhance the catalytic durability in a variety of hydrocarbon transformations, including the MTO reaction [33–39]. The introduced phosphorus oxide interacts with the framework aluminum, thus suppressing the excessive acidity of the zeolite. Mild acidity prevents excess oligomerization causing coke deposition and structural collapse by the release of framework aluminum (de-alumination) under the hydrothermal reaction conditions [37]. However, although the modification of large-pore 10MR (such as MFI) zeolites with phosphorus and its effectiveness on the MTO reaction have been extensively investigated [33–35,37,34–39], conventional post-modification (impregnation) is not possible for small-pore zeolites because of diffusion limitations in the narrow pores. Thus, we synthesized a phosphorus-modified CHA zeolite by direct-phosphorus modification using alkylphosphonium as a phosphorus-modifying agent (P-MA). Sano and Tsunoji et al. investigated zeolite synthesis using FAU zeolite as the starting material (e.g., interzeolite conversion and zeolite hydrothermal conversion) in the presence of tetramethyl or tetraethylphosphonium hydroxides and successfully synthesized phosphorus-modified small-pore zeolites [40–47]. In this method, P-MA is incorporated into the zeolite structure while interacting with the framework during the hydrothermal synthesis. This is similar to the template role played by alkylammonium when acting as an organic structure-directing agent (OSDA). Subsequently, the calcination treatment induces the decomposition and oxidation of P-MA, leading to the formation of phosphoric oxides or acids that interact with the zeolite framework [42,43]. This modification can be applied to different types of zeolite frameworks if appropriate co-existing alkylammonium molecules are selected. To date, the direct phosphorus modification of small-pore zeolites with different framework structures, including AFX, AEI, CHA, and LEV, has been performed [43,45,48,49]. In addition, the high resistance against structural collapse (de-alumination) of the phosphorus-modified samples prepared using the direct method resulted in remarkably higher thermal/hydrothermal stability than that of the unmodified counterpart, and excellent catalytic durability in the selective reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR) [43,45,48,49]. However, the catalytic properties of phosphorus-modified small-pore zeolites have hardly been investigated in the transformation of hydrocarbons and alcohols, despite the importance of these reactions in the chemical industry. Kakiuchi et al. [45] reported the high thermal stability of phosphorus-modified CHA zeolites in the transformation of ethanol to olefin, but where there were no differences between the product selectivity or catalyst lifetime of the modified and unmodified samples. Therefore, in this study, we prepared CHA zeolite catalysts containing different degrees of phosphorus modification and tested their catalytic performance in the MTO reaction. The zeolite samples before and after the MTO reaction were carefully characterized using a combinational analysis method to determine the influence of phosphorus modification on the catalyst lifetime. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the zeolite catalysts The CHA zeolites were hydrothermally synthesized according to a previously reported method [43,45] using trimethyladamanthylammonium hydroxide (TMAdaOH, 25 wt.%, Tokyo Chemical Ind. Co. Ltd., Japan) and tetraethylphosphonium hydroxide (TEPOH) as the OSDA and P-MA, respectively. TEPOH was prepared by treating tetraethylphosphonium bromide (TEPBr, > 98 %, Tokyo Chemical Ind. Co., Japan) with a hydroxide anion exchange resin (DIAION SA10AOH, Mitsubishi Chemical Co., Japan). Dealuminated FAU zeolite (Si/Al = 16), obtained by the treatment of commercial FAU zeolite (HSZ360HUA, Si/Al = 6.8, Tosoh Co., Japan) with sulfuric acid, was used as the silica/alumina source. Sodium hydroxide (> 99 %, NaOH, Kojundo Chemical Laboratory) was used as the alkaline source. TMAdaOH, TEPOH, NaOH, distilled water, and dealuminated FAU zeolite were mixed to obtain a synthesis gel with a composition of 1:0.0625:0.3∼0.03:0∼0.27:0.1:7.5 of Si/Al/TMAdaOH/TEPOH/NaOH/H2O. The resultant gel was transferred to a 100-cm3 Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (stirring-type hydrothermal synthesis reactor, R-100, Hiro Company, Japan) and heated to 150 °C for 7 days at 10 rpm. The obtained solid product was separated by centrifugation and washed thoroughly with deionized water until the pH of the supernatant was close to neutral. The solid was dried overnight at 70 °C yielding the as-synthesized sample. To remove the OSDA from within the sample (and to decompose the P-MA), the as-made zeolites were calcined in air at 600 °C for 10 h (heating rate of 1 °C min−1). Subsequently, the Na+ ions in the calcined zeolites were removed by performing three ion-exchange operations with an aqueous solution of ammonium nitrite (1.5 mol L−1) at 60 °C for 2 h. The obtained NH4 form of the zeolite was calcined at 450 °C for 6 h, yielding the H-form of the zeolite catalysts (CHA, P−CHA(0.19), and P−CHA(0.44)). The degree of phosphorus modification was controlled by the amounts of TMAdaOH and TEPOH in the synthesis gel. The TMAdaOH/Si and TEPOH/Si ratios were set as 0.3 and 0 for CHA, 0.05 and 0.25 for P−CHA(0.19), and 0.03 and 0.27 for P−CHA(0.44). 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a powder X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, PHASER) using graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation at 30 kV and a tube current of 10 mA. Elemental analysis (Si/Al and P/Al ratio) was performed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Seiko SPS7000). The crystal morphology of the sample was observed using a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM). Magic angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectra were collected on an NMR spectrometer (Varian 600PS). The resonance frequencies for 1H, 13C, 27Al, 29Si, and 31P NMR experiments were 600, 151, 156, 119, and 243 MHz, respectively. A zirconia rotor with a 3.2 mm diameter at a rotation speed of 15 kHz was used for the 1H, 27Al, and 31P NMR studies, whereas a 6 mm diameter zirconia rotor at a speed of 7 kHz was used for the 13C and 29Si NMR studies. The chemical shifts for the 1H, 13C, 27Al, 29Si, and 31P MAS NMR spectra were referenced using adamantane, hexamethylbenzene, AlK(SO4)2 12H2O, 3-(trimethylsilyl)propionic-2,2,3,3-d4 acid, and ammonium dihydrogen phosphate, respectively. Prior to the 27Al NMR measurements, the samples were moisture-equilibrated using a saturated solution of ammonium chloride for 24 h. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were obtained using a volumetric apparatus provided by Bel Japan (BELSORPmini) at a measurement temperature of −196 °C. The zeolite sample was heated at 400 °C for 10 h under N2 flow before conducting the measurements. The distribution of acidity in the zeolite samples was determined at 100–700 °C by measuring the NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) curves with a catalyst analyzer (Belcat II, MicrotracBEL, Japan). Helium was used as the carrier gas for the measurements. The samples (∼50 mg) were preheated at 450 °C under a flow of helium (50 mL min−1) and ammonia (NH3/He = 1:99, v/v) was adsorbed at 100 °C. After removing the excess adsorbed ammonia by flushing with helium at 100 °C for 30 min, the samples were heated at a rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.3 MTO reaction The MTO reaction was conducted over the protonated zeolite catalysts at 350 °C in a flow microreactor. Zeolite pellets (100 mg, 50/80 mesh) were loaded into a quartz tubular with a 6 mm inner diameter without a binder. The length of catalyst layer set ca. 16 mm. Helium was used as the carrier gas, and the methanol pressure was set at 5 kPa. The weight to flow (W/F) ratio for methanol was set at 34 g-cat h mol−1. The catalyst was treated under flowing helium at 500 °C for 2 h before the reaction. The MTO reaction products (ethene, propene, butene, paraffins (C1 − C4), over-C5 hydrocarbons, and dimethyl ether (DME)) were analyzed using an on-line gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu) equipped with an HPPLOT/Q capillary column and an FID detector. The methanol conversion and product selectivities were calculated based on the carbon number. The selectivities of the products were based on the carbon numbers from the effluent of the reactor. The conversion of methanol and selectivity of the products was calculated by the formula below. We used FAU zeolite with a Si/Al ratio of 16 as the silica/alumina source and hydrothermally converted it into the CHA zeolite. As shown in the 13C cross-polarization MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 1 ) of the as-synthesized samples, the existence of both P-MA and OSDA is confirmed by the resonance attributed to the tetraethylphosphonium and TMAda cations [43,45]. The relative peak intensity of the tetraethylphosphonium cation increases with an increase in the amount of P-MA in the synthesis gel, while that of the TMAda cation hardly changes. To fabricate the H-form of the zeolite catalysts, the as-synthesized samples were calcined at 600 °C for 10 h and then protonated by ammonium nitrate treatment. The obtained phosphorus-free zeolite catalyst is denoted as CHA and the phosphorus-modified samples are denoted as P−CHA(x), where x indicates the P/Al ratio. Table 1 lists the structural characteristics of the catalysts. We successfully obtained samples with different P/Al ratios (P/Al = 0, 0.19, and 0.44) without significant changes in the Si/Al ratio (approximately 10). The high crystallinity of the materials was confirmed by the strong peak intensities of the powder XRD (PXRD) patterns (Fig. 2 a, left). The peak positions of the samples are consistent with those of the CHA crystal [18] and there were no peaks attributed to the unconverted, starting FAU zeolite nor the impurity phase. Scanning electron microscopy (Fig. 2a, right) reveals that the morphologies of all the CHA samples are similar, where cubic particles with diameters of approximately 0.5–1 μm are observed. The 31P MAS NMR spectra of P−CHA(0.19) and P−CHA(0.44) exhibit resonances from 0 to -40 ppm, and peaks corresponding to tetraethylphosphonium (typically at ∼ 40 ppm) are not observed (Fig. 2b). This confirms successful phosphorus modification via the decomposition of P-MA to phosphorus oxide species, which interact with aluminum in the zeolite framework [43,45,46]. The N2 adsorption isotherms of all the samples exhibit type-I behavior, suggesting that the samples comprise only micropores (Fig. 2c). The relatively high micropore volumes, listed in Table 1, also confirm the high purity of the microporous materials. The microporous volume gradually decreased with an increase in the P/Al ratio of the samples. However, the micropore volume was relatively high even after phosphorus modification, inhibiting excess pore blocking by the phosphorus species and indicating homogeneous phosphorus distribution, similar to previous reports [43,45]. Owing to the similarity in the morphologies of the particles, the external surface areas of the samples were almost identical (approximately 10 m2 g−1). The 27Al MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 3 a) exhibit a dominant peak at 59 ppm corresponding to the aluminum atom tetrahedrally coordinated to four − OSi bonds [5,31], indicating that almost all the aluminum is present in the zeolite framework [5,31]. In contrast, the resonances at approximately 0 and -9 ppm can be assigned to octahedrally coordinated aluminum. The former and latter are due to extra-framework aluminum interacting with water and phosphoric oxide, respectively [34]. In the 29Si MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 3b), three resonances attributed to Q4(2Al) (Si(OAl)2(OSi)2), Q4(1Al) Si(OAl)(OSi)3, and Q4(0Al) Si(OSi)4 are present at -101, -105, and -111 ppm, respectively [5,31]. The relative peak areas of the Q4(2Al), Q4(1Al), and Q4(0Al) structures are 3%, 23 %, and 74 % for CHA, 5%, 21 %, and 74 % for P−CHA(0.19), and 4%, 20 %, and 76 % for P−CHA(0.44), respectively. These similarities in the 29Si chemical states indirectly suggest that the aluminum distribution is similar in all the samples [5]. To investigate the influence of the phosphorus modification on the acidic properties of the zeolite, NH3-TPD was conducted (Fig. 4 ). The unmodified catalyst (CHA) exhibited desorption peaks at different temperatures. The peaks at approximately 540 and 220 °C arise from NH3 desorbed from the weak and strong acid sites, respectively [1,31]. Asymmetric desorption behavior in weak acid site of the P−CHA(0.44) is probably due to the physically adsorbed NH3 on the phosphorus introduced. With an increase in the degree of phosphorus modification, the intensity of the high-temperature peak decreases and that of the middle-temperature peak, at approximately 350 °C, increases. The amounts of strong acid sites determined by the TPD profiles were 0.60, 0.48, and 0.47 mmol g−1 for CHA, P−CHA(0.19), and P−CHA(0.44), respectively, whereas that of middle-temperature peaks 0.04, 0.07, and 0.11 mmol g−1 for CHA, P−CHA(0.19), and P−CHA(0.44), respectively. The change in the acidic properties of the materials after phosphorus introduction is consistent with that observed in a previous study, wherein phosphorus-modified MFI and other zeolites were reported [34,38,45]. This characteristic of the zeolites clearly indicates that the phosphorus species introduced via P-MA interacted with the aluminum in the zeolite framework and reduced the strength of the acid sites. Although there are no liner correlation between the P/Al ratio and the degree of decrease in the strong acid site, this is probably due to the difference in the connecting environment between the phosphorus species introduced. Fig. 5 compares the catalytic performances of the zeolite catalysts containing different degrees of phosphorus modification in the MTO reaction. In the initial stage of the reaction until 1 h of time on stream, the significant change in product selectivity were observed. Especially, the selectivities to ethene and propene were increased, while those to C1–C4 paraffins were decreased from the initial point to 1 h of time on stream. However, in the case of the P−CHA(0.44), the differences in the selectivity between the initial and 1 h of time on stream tend to be smaller than these of other catalysts. In the hydrocarbon pool mechanism in MTO reaction, intermediate aromatics or cyclic alkenes considered to be stored in the zeolite cage after induction period [2]. To gain insight into the intermediate species retained in the zeolites, 13C CP MAS NMR measurement was performed in the catalysts after 1 h of reaction (Fig. 6 ). All catalysts exhibited the resonances at 128 and 30 ppm, assigned to the hydrocarbon pool species in the MTO reaction (methylbenzene etc.), whereas the presence proportions of each carbon species were different among the catalysts. CHA additionally gave sharp resonances at 16 and 59 ppm attributed to dimethyl ether, which is an intermediate in an early stage of the MTO reaction. Therefore, the hydrocarbon pool species and/or initial oligomerization pathway to form hydrocarbon pool species was varied among the samples, which consider to affect the initial product selectivity. For longer reaction time than 1 h, the change in the selectivity was moderated and the relatively high selectivity of ethene and propene were observed in all samples. The ethene and propene selectivities after 1 h of time-on-stream were 23.0 and 38.5 C % for CHA, 23.9 and 39.6 C % for P−CHA(0.19), and 28.7 and 37.5 C % for P−CHA(0.44). Although the propene product selectivities varied according to the time-on-stream, the maximum values barely differed between the reactions performed using the phosphorus-modified and unmodified catalysts. The sum of selectivities of ethene and propene (around 60–80 C %) in the catalysts in this study were comparable to that of SAPO-34 [12,28,29], a silicoaluminophosphate counterpart of CHA zeolite. The selectivities towards other products were relatively low (approximately 5–15 C % at the end of the reaction). These results indicate that it is not the phosphorus modification that is a major factor in light olefin selectivity, but the topology of the CHA zeolite. This result is not contradicted by previous results, which indicate that pore structure is the dominant factor for determining the product selectivity in the MTO reaction [6,22]. In contrast, the catalyst lifetimes were strongly dependent on the P/Al ratio of the catalysts. Although all the catalysts became deactivated after a specific time-on-stream, a conversion of less than 50 % was observed after 4, 5, and 7 h for CHA, P−CHA (0.19), and P−CHA (0.44), respectively. This clearly indicates the suppression of catalyst deactivation by phosphorus modification. In contrast to the small effect of phosphorus modification on the ethene and propene selectivity, CHA and P−CHA(0.19) exhibited relatively high selectivities towards C1–C4 paraffins (19.3 and 16.5 C % for 1 h) compared to that of the long-lived P−CHA(0.44) (11.1 C % for 1 h). In addition, when the propene and butene selectivities in relatively long time on stream was compared between the samples, P−CHA(0.44) tend to exhibit lower selectivities of these products. Considering that such differences is observed in the deactivation period with lower conversion of methanol, the high propene and butene selectivity in CHA and P−CHA(0.19) is likely derived from the differences in the hydrocarbon species near the end of the reaction, implying the change in the acid property among the samples. Deactivation of the MTO catalyst is often connected to paraffin production, which requires hydrogen formed from the dehydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons [22,31]. Thus, the differences in deactivation among the catalysts are likely due to the oligomerization behavior of the hydrocarbons. In contrast, deactivation arising from the structural collapse of the zeolite framework is negligible. As shown in the XRD patterns and 27Al MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 7 a, b), the crystal structure of the CHA zeolite and the tetrahedral coordination of the framework aluminum were preserved in all the samples, even after the MTO reaction. The broad resonance and diffraction peaks are probably due to the deposited coke and the corresponding distortion of the zeolite framework. Although the corresponding 31P MAS NMR spectra (Fig. 7c) retain the peaks ascribed to the phosphorus species that interact with the aluminum in the zeolite framework, they also contain resonances shifted to high-magnetic fields. This indicates that some of the phosphorus was incorporated into the zeolite framework and/or was condensed each other to form polyphosphate species. A similar phenomenon was observed in the phosphorus-modified zeolite after thermal and hydrothermal treatment [46,49]. To investigate the hydrocarbon species retained in the catalyst after the MTO reaction, thermogravimetric differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was performed. The weight loss, together with an exothermic reaction, was observed between 400 and 600 °C, confirming the combustion of the deposited coke species on the catalysts. The amount of coke at the end of the reaction, determined from the TG curves (Fig. 8 a, left), were 18.5 wt% for CHA, 20.0 wt% for P−CHA(0.19), and 19.2 wt% for P−CHA(0.44). Similar amounts of coke suggest that the maximum coke capacity among the catalysts was similar, which is not contradicted by the similar particle sizes of the samples. In contrast, the DTA curves of the phosphorus-modified samples tend to exhibit exothermic peaks at lower temperatures, implying the presence of more combustible species with different structural distributions. The chemical state of these hydrocarbons was directly observed by 13C CP MAS NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 8b). The resonances at 23 ppm and 38 ppm can be assigned to the non-aromatic (methyl and branched) carbons [14,15,17]. In contrast, the peaks between 130 and 150 ppm are attributed to aromatic carbons [12,23,27]. Unlike the aromatic carbon signals, the methyl carbon signal tends to increase with an increase in the degree of phosphorus modification of the catalyst. This revealed a decrease in the aromaticity of the hydrocarbon species when applying the phosphorus-modified catalyst, which can be explained by the suppression of oligomerization (polymerization) between the methyl-aromatic species (such as methyl benzene). Since polymerization of the aromatic ring involves hydrogen production, this hypothesis does not contradict the catalytic results, yielding higher amounts of paraffins in the un-modified sample. To gain quantitative insight into the structural distribution of the hydrocarbons, 1H MAS NMR measurements were conducted. Several resonances attributed to the protons of the hydrocarbons and hydroxy groups were observed. The signal at 1.2 ppm corresponds to the hydrogen atoms bound to the methyl and methylene carbon, while that at approximately 2–3.5 ppm is assigned to the proton in the methyl or branched carbons bound to the aromatic groups [12]. In addition, the peak at approximately 7.5 ppm is attributed to the hydrogen atoms of the aromatic rings [12]. In contrast, the resonances at approximately 5 and 10 ppm can be assigned to the proton atoms of the adsorbed water, zeolite acid sites and silanol groups with hydrogen-bonding, respectively [50]. To evaluate the degree of oligomerization of the hydrocarbons, the relative amount of non-aromatic proton was estimated based on the area of the peaks at 1.2 and 2–3.5 ppm and it plotted against the P/Al ratio of the sample (Fig. 9 ). The value increased with an increase in the P/Al ratio, confirming the inhibition of oligomerization and formation of polymerized aromatics. The formation of polycyclic aromatics from intermediate hydrocarbons caused the deactivation from coking, which was reported in a previous paper [12]. Considering that there were hardly any differences in the physicochemical properties of the samples, except for the loading level of phosphorus, we concluded that the phosphorus modification inhibited excess oligomerization and prolonged the lifetime of the catalyst employed in the MTO reaction. The modulation in the acidity by the phosphorus modification likely affect the hydrocarbon oligomeriztion in MTO reaction. However, the direct changing the reaction space of hydrocarbon by the phosphorus introduction should not be ignored because the modification also induced the decrease of micropore volume as shown in the result of N2 adsorption. 4 Conclusion Phosphorus-modified CHA zeolites with different P/Al ratios were synthesized and their catalytic performances in the MTO reaction were evaluated. The evaluation probed the effectiveness of modifying small-pore (CHA) zeolites with phosphorus in enhancing the catalytic lifetime of the MTO reaction. The characteristics of the zeolite catalysts before and after the reaction revealed that the the phosphorus modification tuned the oligomerization behavior of the hydrocarbons in the zeolite pore system to inhibit coke deposition. Since direct-phosphorus modification can be extended to various zeolite frameworks, it can contribute to diversifying durable and selective MTO catalysts. Reducing the amount of framework aluminum [22,31] and crystal size [9,11,28,29] are well-known methods for improving the catalytic durability in MTO reactions. However, the present phosphorus modification can be regarded as an additional tool for further improvement of the catalytic ability of the MTO reaction when it can be combined with different synthetic strategies. In addition, initial product selectivity and 13C NMR measurement suggest that the intermediate state of hydrocarbon during the MTO reaction was also affected from the phosphorus modification. Thus, considering the many mechanistic studies previously performed [2,32], this new type of phosphorus-modified catalyst would be an interesting addition to the scientific research field of MTO catalysis. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performance of phosphorus-modified CHA zeolites, synthesized by direct phosphorus modification using tetraethylphosphonium as a phosphorus-modifying agent (P-MA), was investigated for the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) reaction. Comparative catalytic testing in the MTO reaction revealed that the phosphorus modification effectively prolonged the catalyst lifetime while hardly affecting the ethene and propene selectivities. The initial ethene and propene selectivities over CHA zeolite with P/Al ratio of 0.44 were 28.7 and 37.5 C %, respectively, and the catalytic life time improved from 4 to 7 h compared with the catalyst without phosphorus modification. The relative amount of non-aromatic hydrocarbons retained in the zeolite catalysts with respect to those of the aromatic ones increased with increasing degree of phosphorus modification. This demonstrates that the suppression of excess oligomerization of the hydrocarbon species results in a prolonged lifetime in the phosphorus-modified catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Controlling hydrocarbon oligomerization in phosphorus-modified CHA zeolite for a long-lived methanol-to-olefin catalyst
